title: Locksmith Terms
description: Unlock your knowledge of the fascinating vocabulary used by locksmiths and security professionals.

questions.question: What is a 'tumbler' in a lock?
options: A drinking glass-shaped lock
A spring-loaded component inside a lock that must be moved to a specific position by the correct key
A type of padlock
A lock that has fallen off

questions.question: What does 'keying alike' mean?
options: Making keys that look similar
Setting multiple locks to be opened by the same key
Creating duplicate keys
Keys made from the same material

questions.question: What is a 'deadbolt'?
options: A decorative door bolt
A bolt struck by lightning
A broken bolt
A lock bolt that is moved into position by turning a key or thumb turn, with no spring mechanism

questions.question: What does 'rekeying' a lock involve?
options: Making a copy of the existing key
Changing the internal pins or tumblers so a different key operates the lock
Removing the lock entirely
Buying a new lock

questions.question: What is a 'master key' system?
options: The most expensive key available
A key made by a master locksmith
A key that can never be duplicated
A system where individual keys open specific locks, but one master key opens all locks in the group

questions.question: What is a 'cylinder' in a lock?
options: The part of the lock into which the key is inserted and turned
A type of safe
The shape of a padlock
A round door handle

questions.question: What does 'pick' mean in locksmithing?
options: Breaking a lock with force
Using a specialized tool to manipulate the internal components of a lock to open it without a key
Selecting the right key for a lock
Choosing a lock at the store

questions.question: What is a 'strike plate'?
options: A decorative door plate
A plate on the back of a lock
A plate that has been hit
The metal plate mounted on the door frame into which the bolt extends when the door is locked

questions.question: What is 'key bitting'?
options: A key that bites your finger
The key's brand marking
The specific cut pattern of ridges and valleys on a key that correspond to the lock's tumblers
Biting a key to test its metal

questions.question: What is a 'bump key'?
options: A large oversized key
A key that vibrates when used
A specially cut key that can be used with a tapping technique to open pin tumbler locks
A key with bumps on the handle

questions.question: What does 'mortise lock' mean?
options: A lock that fits into a pocket (mortise) cut into the edge of a door
A very old-fashioned lock
A lock for a mortuary
A lock made of mortar

questions.question: What is a 'shackle' on a padlock?
options: The keyhole
The body of the lock
The U-shaped metal loop that passes through the hasp or chain
The locking mechanism inside

questions.question: What does 'key blank' refer to?
options: A key that doesn't work
A key with no markings
A fake key used for display
An uncut key that will be machined to fit a specific lock

questions.question: What is 'access control' in the security industry?
options: Controlling who has access to keys
A type of padlock
A system that regulates who can enter a building or area, using cards, codes, or biometrics
Locking all doors at night

questions.question: What does 'tension wrench' do in lock picking?
options: Measures the tension of a lock spring
Applies slight rotational pressure to the lock cylinder while pins are being manipulated
Tightens loose lock screws
Removes a broken key from a lock
